intro: Fimbristylis mozambicensis, commonly known as the Mozambique sedge, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cyperaceae. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in wet or marshy habitats, often found in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets. It is characterized by its fibrous roots and its ability to thrive in waterlogged soils. Fimbristylis mozambicensis plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various small organisms in its native environment.
